file_name: German-made FinSpy spyware found in Egypt, and Mac and Linux versions revealed _ Amnesty International

rewrite.Initial Access: Amnesty International's Security Lab discovered that the NilePhish attacker group distributed FinSpy spyware through a fake Adobe Flash Player download website, flash.browserupdate[.]download. The site offered a backdoored version of Flash Player, which upon clicking would download FinSpy. The dropper was designed to retrieve the final payload from the server at http://172.241.27[.]171/support/personal.asp, which was offline at the time of analysis. The backdoored Flash Player version (32.0.0.269) had a creation date of September 20, 2019, indicating recent activity around that time.
rewrite.Others: Amnesty International's Security Lab reported on the use of FinSpy, a surveillance software suite produced by Munich-based FinFisher Gmbh, which has been used to target Human Rights Defenders (HRDs) in various countries. The report detailed the discovery of new samples of FinSpy for Windows, Android, and previously undisclosed versions for Linux and MacOS. The report aims to aid cybersecurity research and raise awareness among HRDs about evolving digital attack techniques. The report also revealed that the NilePhish attacker group, likely state-sponsored, has been involved in distributing FinSpy and testing Cobalt Strike, a penetration testing suite. The report includes technical analysis of the FinSpy samples, their capabilities, and the infection chain for MacOS and Linux versions. Additionally, the report provides indicators of compromise and acknowledges contributions from Esther Onfroy and Maciek Kotowicz.
